about.content: At K≈†C, we are dedicated to practicing martial traditions of medieval and Renaissance Europe. We train with longswords, sabres, and more ‚Äî focusing on skill, athletic performance, history, and community. Whether you're a beginner or experienced fencer, you'll find a welcoming place to learn and grow here.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.subtitle: Get in touch with us through any of the following channels. We're here to answer your questions and help you start your HEMA journey!

content1.paragraph: HEMA, or Historical European Martial Arts, is the modern revival of Europe's forgotten fighting traditions. It's based on historical manuals and brings centuries-old martial traditions back to life through training and sparring

content2.paragraph: Unlike choreographed swordfighting you see in movies or historical re-enactments, HEMA is a martial art. Every move is rooted in historical sources and tested against a resisting partner. It's not about performing ‚Äî it's about understanding how real swordplay works

content3.paragraph: The duels we study were fought in ordinary clothes, not armor, and our gear needs to reflect that. HEMA uses modern protective elements made from puncture-resistant fabrics and durable plastics. It's inspired by history but designed for safety, comfort, and mobility

content4.paragraph: HEMA offers the full package of a martial art. We train strength, endurance, coordination, and awareness ‚Äî but also the mindset to push through the limits. Confidence, skill, and friendships are forged through the shared challenge of mastering this complex but rewarding discipline

join.intro: If you feel like starting fencing, you have two options: either wait for our recruitment event, which we hold once or twice a year, or join our already formed group of advanced fencers. Choose the path that suits you best.

beginner.title: Recruitment
content: Our recruitment events are designed for complete beginners who want to start their HEMA journey the right way. We provide all necessary equipment, including protective gear and training weapons, so you can focus on learning the fundamentals.

During these structured courses, you'll learn proper techniques, safety protocols, and basic combat principles in a supportive environment with fellow beginners. This is the ideal path if you want to build a solid foundation before committing to purchasing your own equipment.

advanced.title: Advanced Group
content: This path is for those who already have experience with fencing or martial arts, or are absolutely certain that HEMA is their calling. You'll train alongside experienced fencers with full gear and real weapons, not plastic trainers.

This route requires dedication and a financial commitment‚Äîyou'll need to purchase your own equipment and weapons as soon as possible (we can provide guidance and help with purchases). It's more challenging, but if you're committed and confident that HEMA is for you, this is the most efficient and fastest way to learn and grow as a fencer.

swordAndBuckler.name: Sword and Buckler
swordAndBuckler.description: Sword-and-buckler fencing is closest in spirit to rapier-and-dagger principles. With a buckler, however, some techniques work differently, as they are adapted to its specific shape and role in parries and deflections of the opponent's weapon.

longsword.name: Longsword
longsword.description: Longsword fencing is currently the most widespread HEMA discipline in the world. In our club it forms the core of the training system. The principles you learn with the longsword are universal and become the foundation for mastering other historical weapons.

sabre.name: Sabre
sabre.description: The sabre brings together the principles of one-handed swordplay. In our club it is the second most common weapon. Technically it is less demanding to pick up than the longsword ‚Äì more intuitive, but with greater emphasis on tactics. It is an excellent complement to longsword fencing.

rapier.name: Rapier
rapier.description: Rapier fencing is a very distinctive discipline within historical fencing. Most often the rapier is paired with a dagger in the off hand, creating a combination of defense and attack. Both hands work together simultaneously and complement each other throughout the exchange.

faq.description: Find answers to common questions about training, equipment, and club membership.
faq.noResultsMessage: Didn't find the answer to your question?

questions.question: Do I need any prior experience?
answer: If you join through our recruitment group, you don't need any previous experience. Training is adapted to the group and we progress at a pace that suits most people.
If you decide to join the advanced group, previous experience with fencing or martial arts will help you adapt more quickly to the training routine.
In any case, enthusiasm, consistency in training, and willingness to learn are what matter most üôÇ

questions.question: What should I bring to training?
answer: For beginners in the recruitment group, we provide basic equipment ‚Äì fencing mask, gorget, plastic chest protector, and training weapons. You only need to bring comfortable sports clothing, indoor shoes, and a bottle of water.
If you decide to join outside the recruitment periods, you'll need to acquire your own gear and weapon as soon as possible. We'll gladly help you choose and buy the right equipment.

questions.question: Which weapons do you train with?
answer: At K≈†C we primarily focus on longsword and sabre fencing. If you join us through the recruitment course, the first months of your training program will be based on the principles of the German longsword school.
We also encourage members to experiment with other weapons, and among our fencers you'll find people who regularly train with sabre, rapier, or sword and buckler.

questions.question: Can I train with my own weapon?
answer: Yes, if you already have your own weapon you can bring it to training. For contact sparring it has to meet certain criteria, both for safety and to avoid excessive wear on your partner's weapon and gear.
If you're not sure whether your weapon is suitable, we'll gladly help you choose, inspect, or adjust it.

questions.question: How much does membership cost?
answer: Membership fees are 40 EUR per month for beginners in the recruitment group and 20 EUR per month for advanced fencers. We keep fees as low as possible ‚Äì their purpose is mainly to cover hall rent and equipment maintenance.

questions.question: How much does the gear cost?
answer: Full HEMA equipment is not cheap ‚Äì depending on the quality and brand it can easily reach several hundred euros (we strongly recommend not cutting corners on safety gear). The good news is that as a beginner in the recruitment group, you don't have to invest into your own gear right away, since we provide the basic equipment.
You can buy your own equipment and weapon gradually, as your budget allows.

questions.question: Is HEMA dangerous?
answer: Like any contact sport, HEMA carries inherent risks. But you don't need to worry ‚Äì injuries are very rare in beginner training. At first we focus on stance, basic techniques, and conditioning; light sparring with foam weapons is optional.

As your skills grow and you move to steel weapons, safety becomes an even higher priority. Everyone must wear proper protective gear during contact training and use weapons that meet safety standards.

questions.question: How often do you train?
answer: We train three times per week: Monday and Wednesday 17:00‚Äì18:30, and Friday 17:00‚Äì20:00. We try to balance technical instruction for beginners, advanced fencers, and free sparring.
The exact schedule can change over the year depending on season, hall availability, and member needs.

questions.question: Can I try a trial class?
answer: It depends on the current situation and group capacity. The best option is to contact us directly and arrange a date.
If joining a training session isn't possible at the moment, we'll at least invite you to visit, show you how things work here, and answer all your questions üôÇ

questions.question: What age groups do you accept?
answer: We primarily train adults and teenagers (15+). For underage applicants, parental consent is required.

questions.question: Do you compete in tournaments?
answer: Yes, our members can compete in local and international HEMA tournaments. Competing is optional, but we encourage anyone who feels ready to test their skills.

questions.question: Do you also do shows or demonstrations?
answer: The main focus of K≈†C is regular training and developing the fencing skills of our members. From time to time, however, we organize demonstrations at historical events or schools to raise awareness about the sport and attract new members.
If you are interested in such a demonstration or collaboration, feel free to contact us.
